most believe that no single solution exist to effectively mitigate this threat .
instead , a menu of option may be consider , include install infrared -lrb- ir -rrb- countermeasure on aircraft ; modify flight operation and air traffic control procedure ; improve airport and regional security ; and strengthen missile non-proliferation effort .
equip aircraft with missile countermeasure system can protect the aircraft even when operate in area where ground-based security measure be unavailable or infeasible to implement .
however , this option have a relatively high cost , between $ 1 million and $ 3 million per aircraft , and the time need for implementation do not allow for immediate response to the exist terrorist threat .
procedural improvement such as specific flight crew training , alter air traffic procedure to minimize exposure to the threat , and improve security near airport may be less costly than countermeasure and could more immediately help deter domestic terrorist attack .
however , these technique by themselves can not completely mitigate the risk of domestic attack and would not protect U.S. airliner fly to and from foreign airport .
legislation introduce in the 108th Congress -lrb- H.R. 580 , S. 311 -rrb- call for the installation of missile defense system in all turbojet aircraft use in schedule air carrier service .

it be anticipate that at the conclusion of this program , in January 2006 , the Department of Homeland Security will be able to provide a detailed analysis of the suitability of such system for use to protect commercial passenger aircraft .

Byrne 2004-12-12T14:47:00 Conglomerates be a fascinating species : the standard definition be ' a company involve in multiple unrelated business ' but the more accurate definition would be ' a company that rely on financial pyrotechnics , balance sheet juggling , and adroit accounting to create the illusion of growth ' .
I love to write about they , but I would hate to own one , since most of they market value come from the market 's assumption that the company 's leader will somehow find a way to retroactively justify they overvaluation .
usually , it do not work , but when it do the result can be spectacularly entertaining .
for a while -lrb- see ling-temco-vought or Tyco for detail -rrb- .
the recent rumor about WalMart 's plan to buy out a shipping company have give rise to the fear that the company may go the conglomerate route .
they have many of the symptom of a late-stage conglomerate : a gigantic main business with slow growth , fear that competition will substantially reduce the profitability of they main business , a shareholder base that include many people who own only WalMart stock -lrb- thus provide another incentive for intracompany diversification -rrb- , and enough resource to pull it off on a grand scale .
I can understand the concern , but I do not see the motivation .
as a retailer of just about everything , WalMart can expand into some pretty broadly-defined area without go beyond either they core competency or some arena where they can cut cost .
after all , add some international shipping asset to they holding would be a natural extension of they enormously successful practice of buy the distribution network for they product .
they be come close to Smithfield Food 's very successful ` squeal to meal ' policy ; if these rumor be true , the result for shareholder will be a pretty positive one .

.

Byrne 2005-02-04T13:37:00 accord to the usually reliable cnn/money , the `` Twin Deficits '' will continue to grow .
interesting terminology ... I believe they be refer to the budget deficit and ... the capital surplus ?
when analyze trade deficit , it be important to realize that the amount by which import exceed export be also equal to the net amount foreign investor have bet on the US .
so the trade deficit be due to a confluence of the pressure from US consumer -lrb- who control about 20 % of global gdp -rrb- and everybody else -lrb- exclude the non-consumption share of US GDP , that would amount to around 75 % of global gdp -rrb- .
which of those be -- probably -- go to be a more important number ?
even if we be consumer bent on gorge ourselves with import goods , the largest pressure on the deficit be that we be simply a better place for investment -- higher return on capital in develop country be more than mitigate by the higher political risk they face .

John A 2004-12-24t10:07:00 for my holiday post , I offer a message of hope for the business world .
in 1994 , I be a graduate student in Boston .
I be ask to moderate a panel discussion on social entrepreneurship for a conference at Harvard Business School .
the conference be be hold by a new group call student for responsible business .
I expect to see a small gathering of idealistic , slightly naive MBA student .
what I find be a packed room of 200 intelligent , practical , driven idealist .
these student be determine to figure out how to use business as a driver for positive social change .
I leave that room with my eye open to the possibility present by these future business leader .
fast forward 10 year .
student for responsible business be now call net impact .
in 2004 , I have the opportunity to attend they conference host by the University of Texas McCombs Business School .
net impact have grow to include over 9,000 MBA student and alumnus .
approximately 900 people attend the 2004 conference .
the buzz word fly around the conference include social entrepreneurship , sustainable profitability , work with passion .
I meet student after student intent on harness the force of business and capitalism to improve the world .
these student understand that business be a powerful lever of change in this world .
recently business school have receive they share of criticism for turn out graduate who seem to have lose sight of they responsibility for ethical action .
I can tell you that I be see a powerful groundswell of change come from within business school .
it be not come from the faculty , or the alumnus , or the administration .
all these group continue to pay lipservice to topic of social responsibility while avoid any real innovation in the student experience .
the change be be demand by the student .
a little secret of business school be that MBA student have a immense amount of sway .
few choose to use it , but if they want they can fundamentally change they school .
right now student at business school be ask for more discussion of these topic in class , be initiate service project , form support group for social entrepreneur , invite speaker to campus to discuss sustainability , social investing , non-profit innovation , etc. .
net impact be often at the center of these effort .
these be not isolate event ... this be a revolution from within .
I have no doubt that in 10 year we will see the vast positive impact that these student be have in the world of business and society at large .
in 1776 Adam Smith speak of enlighten self-interest in the wealth of nation .
I often feel that we have conveniently forget he emphasis on enlighten which he define as be commit to be a good citizen and steward of society .
I be excited and hopeful that this new generation of business leader will bring this emphasis front and center .
if you be a MBA student and want a good reference for compare how MBA program integrate issue of sustainability and social responsibility into the student experience a good place to start be the Beyond Grey Pinstripes report produce by the Aspen Institute .
happy holiday to everyone !!
John A 2005-01-03T09:44:00 here be a entertaining little morsel from Business Week Online -lrb- no byline give -rrb- : but on the subject of succession , those two look like role model compare with insurance giant American International Group Inc. -lrb- AIG -rrb- , whose aging ceo have no plan to retire .
Maurice R. `` Hank '' Greenberg , who turn 80 in May , groom two son to be successor , but both have since leave AIG.Greenberg Sr. then create a office of the chairman in 2002 , which include co-coo Martin J. Sullivan and Donald P. Kanak .
both be consider possible successor , but the board will not know Greenberg 's preference until he departure , when it open a sealed letter .
perhaps this be a good time for a quick refresher ... .
the CEO work for the board ... end lesson .
I guess it be not as straight forward when you ceo be also chairman and one of the largest shareholder .
it would be tempting to get on my high horse right now about the need to separate the position of CEO and Chairman but to be honest with you I do not really believe that .
I know CEO/chair duality be a popular cause for corporate governance .
however there be little empirical evidence to suggest that separate these role affect firm performance in either a positive or negative way .
have a combined ceo/chairman do reduce the ability of the board to act as a check on management and this do mean that you need to be more critical in you assessment of the trustworthiness of the top management team .
this downside of have a combined CEO/chair be offset by -lrb- 1 -rrb- a reduction of coordination and communication cost at the top of the organization and -lrb- 2 -rrb- a increase in the negotiate position of the CEO when deal with supplier , potential merger partner , etc. # 2 could be particularly useful in a dynamic industry .
I do however look more carefully at the top management team of a company with a ceo/chair before invest .
it be important that you can get a sense of the trustworthiness of the CEO .
be there high turnover among senior manager ?
be there a record of regulatory problem ?
if the CEO be new , I also look at the performance of the CEO 's previous company .
I be most concerned if the fortune of the prior employer take a sudden turn for the worse after the CEO leave .

John A 2005-01-08T13:23:00 it be just about time for Fortune magazine to release its 2005 list of 100 best company to work for .
so now be a good time to ask a simple question : why should we care ?
make this list be certainly a source of pride .
it can also be helpful if you be look for a nice new job .
should anyone else pay attention to this list ?
well , thanks for ask because I just happen to have a answer for that question .
it turn out that investor can benefit by pay attention to this list as well .
in a study publish in the Journal of Business Finance & Accounting -lrb- 2003 , 30:771 -798 -rrb- , Greg Filbeck and Dianna Preece find that company on the Fortune list of 100 best company to work for outperform a match sample of firm along multiple measure of return .
this study be particularly relevant for investor because the author measure return after the list be announce .
to often these study use as a start point the moment before information become public .
the only way to benefit from such information be by hold the stock before the information become public .
this study indicate that the best company to work for information may still be useful even after the information become public .
it might also be useful to look at company that have consistently make the list in the previous few year and make a educate guess about they inclusion on this year 's list .
search the news archive and see if in the past year the company do anything that might have totally piss off they employee .
massive layoff , bitter union battle , stop offer free massage , etc. .
you might also want to be wary if the CEO or a bunch of other top executive have be replace .
that can often generate a period of uncertainty in a workforce .

it may take a couple year , and several more financial filings -lrb- on time of course -rrb- , before I be persuade to take a second look at the company .
the bottom line be that I rely on SEC filings to assess company and I do not want to have any doubt about the veracity of the information contain in these document .
in Nortel 's defense , they have just go through the perfect storm in the telecommunications equipment sector .
the whole industry overbuilt and get blindside by the tech downturn .
this could be describe as a growth industry that go on a bender and be now try to recover from the hangover .
I have always feel that you learn a lot about someone when you see how they try to recover from a hangover -lrb- pause for brief college flashback -rrb- .
this be a great time to assess organizational effectiveness in the telecommunications equipment industry .
Nortel and Lucent attempt to hide the damage -lrb- what do you mean ?
I be not drunk ! -rrb-
and hope for a uptick in demand before they would have to come clean .
both company have be penalize for these action and have continue to restructure operation , sell asset , and layoff employee .
Cisco , on the other hand , be able to take one huge restructuring charge in 2001 and move forward .
they ability to do this and have it work -lrb- so far -rrb- indicate a very deep and impressive understanding of they organization .
especially when compare to its competitor , Cisco seem to be back in fight form due to it be ability to rapidly assess its organizational structure and reconfigure to meet the change market .
not bad for a company with a hangover !

John A 2005-02-03T21:02:00 socially responsible investing .
corporate social responsibility .
just say these word seem to elicit some fairly simplistic knee-jerk reaction .
the reaction that I find most amusing be the know look of sympathy .
you know , the one that say `` Poor naive soul .
if only you understand economics , you would understand the folly of you way . ''
I do not intend to get into the stakeholder vs stockholder debate here or argue the relative merit of Atlas Shrugged .
those discussion , though interesting , avoid a simpler question .
do measure of corporate social responsibility contain valuable add information that help investor pick win investment ?
if all that you have read about this topic be a article in Business Week or the Wall Street Journal , you have probably hear the standard answer -- the evidence be mixed .
that be true but not very reveal would not you say ?
evidence be mixed mostly because -lrb- 1 -rrb- there be little agreement about how to measure social responsibility and -lrb- 2 -rrb- many current measure toss together a heap of information that have no business be lump together .
Social responsibility often include everything from treatment of employee to type of product produce .
there be not really any reason to believe that sell gun or tobacco have anything to do with force employee to work unpaid overtime .
yet both get lump together in the socially responsible invest discussion .
once you start to break apart social responsibility into its various component , you start to see the valuable information .
company that have poor employee relation tend to underperform , as do company that pollute at a higher rate than they industry peer .
on the other hand , company with numerous nlrb violation do not do worse than they peer and company that sell you typical `` sin '' product -lrb- tobacco , firearm , gambling -rrb- can be excellent investment .
lump all these thing together and of course you will get mixed result .
take separately , they provide valuable information about future firm performance .
I guess it be time to get beyond the image of the greedy capitalist vs. hippie tree hugger in this discussion .
though that would make a great Celebrity Death Match episode .
here be abstract from 16 significant study about socially responsible investing and a interesting essay on the subject .
John A 2005-02-04T11:55:00 yesterday be a tough day for the Seattle scene .
Amazon end the day down 14.6 % .
starbuck down 8.2 % .
I should disclose that I spend a few year live in Seattle and I have a soft spot in my heart for all thing Seattle .
as far as I could tell , many people in the Northwest spend the morning drink latte and they evening drink microbrew .
really not a bad lifestyle .
anyway , back on topic here .
market over reaction ?
hard to say .
both company have pricey stock and those valuation be base on optimistic expectation of future growth .
yesterday 's news lead many to question they growth assumption for these company .
today I want to talk a bit about Starbucks .
I think I have to start by acknowledge that the stock be still pricey even after its drop yesterday .
however , my organizational indicator analysis reveal a very low level of business risk .
this may partially justify a higher P/E ratio .
a couple week ago , I observe that Wal-Mart have offset strong and weak organizational indicator .
Starbucks , on the other hand , have uniformly strong organizational indicator .
Starbucks score as best in its industry on six of seven organizational indicator .
not surprising be its strong score in the employee relation and stakeholder action indicator .
its weakest score be in the external reporting indicator .
in the past , several observer have raise concern about aggressive accounting at Starbucks but my analysis do not indicate any systematic current issue .
the weak score be primarily the result of Starbucks current strategy of increase equity ownership of several foreign subsidiary .
this be a strategic shift that have short-term cost and add some uncertainty to the financial statement .
beyond the strong organizational indicator analysis , several additional factor favor Starbucks ability to continue to grow revenue .
1 .
Starbucks have little debt .
Starbucks be not currently finance its growth with debt .
consider its growth , this be amazing .
it also mean that Starbucks have a large amount of flexibility in how it finance future growth .
the company can assume much more debt without negatively affect its risk profile because ... 2 .
Starbucks have a healthy cashflow and current cash position .
this allow the company to grow without debt .
you could argue that Starbucks have too much cash and should do more to pass it on to shareholder .
this option be another way that Starbucks have retain its flexibility for the future .
3 .
Starbucks be the primary owner of its store and limit franchise .
while Starbucks do partner -lrb- airline , airport , Barnes & Noble -rrb- , most of its store be company own .
from a managerial perspective this greatly simplify cost structure , product change , and quality control .
take together all of these factor paint a picture of a company with a very strong future .
I can not say if these factor justify the current share price but I would say that they justify a higher P/E ratio than the industry norm .
risk be lower .
interesting aside : Starbucks be take over the location in my town that be recently abandon by Krispy Kreme .
disclosure : at the time of this write I do not own Starbucks stock ... but I be tempt and might consider a buy next week .
I be also tempt to go buy a latte after write this post .
